awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Horses and Human Societies in the American West
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers seeking to understand the complex interactions between present-day environmental and cultural change increasingly turn to historical datasets, which enable examination of such interactions over the long term. This project uses historical and archaeological data to model human responses to one of the most important socio-environmental changes in human history: the dispersal of the domestic horse into the Americas in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries. The project promotes collaborative research with and public outreach to indigenous groups, supports an early-career researcher and the development of scientific facilities and public education at the University of Colorado, and funds the education of students at three western universities (including a Hispanic-serving institution). Results of the project are to be disseminated through both the scientific literature, popular media, and a museum exhibit, as well as a series of seminars bringing together scholars and indigenous leaders. In doing so, this project establishes an analytical framework for understanding the complex interaction between species dispersals, environmental changes, ecological factors, and cultural transformations that built our modern world.

After their introduction to the Americas domestic horses revolutionized life across the plains and deserts of North America, giving rise to the great horse cultures of the plains and deserts and forming the backbone of economically and militarily dominant Native empires during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries. Despite the obvious importance of horses in later history, however, gaps in the historic record mean that little is known about when, why, or how the first horses were first integrated into Native societies across most of the American West. Applying techniques including radiocarbon dating, ancient DNA sequencing, zooarchaeology, and stable isotopes analysis to ancient horse remains, this project produces a scientific model for when and how domestic horses dispersed into the continent, and in so doing explains the ways horses impacted life in early historic America.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Horses and Human Societies in the American West project explored the questions of when, why, and how domestic horses transformed the societies and daily lives of Native American groups. To accomplish this goal, our research team combined approaches from zooarchaeology and archaeological science with historical and ethnohistoric data to produce a detailed temporal model for the dispersal and adoption of domestic horses. This model allowed us to compare how horses were adopted and used across the American Southwest, the Great Basin, and the Great Plains. By placing Indigenous horsemanship in a broad chronological, ecological, and geographic context, this project rewrote our understanding of human-horse relations in the recent history of North America. Our goals were accomplished by completing three major initiatives: 1) Modeling the dispersal of horses into Indigenous societies in North America; 2) Identifying Indigenous horse breeding, management, and care; 3) Assessing the impacts of the domestic horses on Indigenous peoples of North America.

 

The major goal of this portion of our collaborative proposal undertaken at the University of Oklahoma was to use qualitative data analysis software to build and critically analyze a comprehensive database of community-, regional-, and national-level historic and ethnographic documents that was used to inform our archaeological results and assess both small- and large-scale impacts of horses across western North America. We had two specific objectives when developing our database. First, we wanted to collect documentary evidence that links and informs our archaeological data, specifically coding for information relating to chronology (introduction and spread of horses), mechanisms (how horses spread across the country), and husbandry (Indigenous management systems, diet, healthcare, etc.). Second, we coded for themes relating to both regional and broader research questions centering on the impact of horses on Indigenous lifeways. From this database we created a timeline that noted instances of horse acquisition and ownership by various groups across the project area that was used to inform our model for when horses arrived at Indigenous communities and how quickly they spread across the continent through Indigenous trade networks. This database was also used in presentations and publications, including our collaborative research paper in Science (Taylor et al. 2023).
